p: Phylogenies provide a potentially powerful tool for predicting generalizable patterns of species phenological response (Davis, Willis, Primack, & Miller‐Rushing, 2010). Flowering phenology is one of several plant functional traits that have been found to exhibit phylogenetic signal, that is, the tendency of closely related species to flower at the similar time during the year (Davies et al., 2013; Du et al., 2015; Willis et al., 2008; Wright & Calderon, 1995). There is little evidence that leaf‐out phenology also exhibits phylogenetic signal (Davies et al., 2013; Panchen et al., 2014). Whether phenological response to climate (i.e., climate‐driven phenological shifts) exhibits phylogenetic signal, however, remains an open question. This is due, in part, to the limited number of studies that have tested for phylogenetic signal in phenological response (Davis et al., 2010).
